revision.text:
{{Infobox Organization |name = Comic Book Legal Defense Fund |image = Cbldf.png |leader_title = Executive Director |leader_name = Charles Brownstein |slogan = |purpose = Protect the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] rights of [[comics]] creators, publishers, and retailers |membership = |headquarters = [[New York City|New York]], [[New York (state)|NY]] |formation = {{start date and age|1986}} |website = [http://www.cbldf.org www.cbldf.org] }}
The '''Comic Book Legal Defense Fund''' ('''CBLDF''') is an [[United States|American]] [[non-profit organization]] formed in 1986 to protect the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] rights of [[comics]] creators, publishers, and retailers covering legal expenses. The Executive Director is Charles Brownstein, who has served in that capacity since 2002.<ref>[http://cbldf.org/about-us/staff/ "Staff"]. Comic Book Legal Defense Fund. Retrieved October 29, 2012.</ref>
The CBLDF is supported by many big names of the industry; the board of directors includes [[Chris Staros]], [[Peter David]], and [[Neil Gaiman]]. ''Fund Comics'', ''More Fund Comics'', and ''Even More Fund Comics'' are compilations of short work by famous artists sold to support the CBLDF. Additionally, [[Black Phoenix Alchemy Lab]] offers a line of perfumes whose profits go directly to the CBLDF.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbldf.org/articles/archives/000311.shtml |title=Comic Book Legal Defense Fund: Smell the Neil Gaiman Collection |date=February 1, 2007 |publisher=Comic Book Legal Defense Fund |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070622184852/http://www.cbldf.org/articles/archives/000311.shtml |archivedate=2007-06-22 |df= }}</ref> Popular artists such as comedian [[Bill Hader]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bdMZEiXpZEg |title=Bill Hader for the Comic Book Legal Defense Fund |publisher=[[YouTube]] |date=April 19, 2008}}</ref> cartoonist [[Jeff Smith (cartoonist)|Jeff Smith]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qxzxcORrgBE |title=Jeff Smith for the Comic Book Legal Defense Fund |publisher=[[YouTube]] |date=April 22, 2008}}</ref> and comic book artist [[Frank Miller (comics)|Frank Miller]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HyDIbbbuS_U |title=Frank Miller for the Comic Book Legal Defense Fund |publisher=[[YouTube]] |date=April 22, 2008}}</ref> have expressed support for it.
The CBLDF is a sponsor of [[Banned Books Week]]; and also works with libraries, helping to keep graphic novels on their shelves. In the past they have partnered with such organizations as the Kids Right to Read Project, the [[American Library Association]], and the Office of Intellectual Freedom as part of this mission.
==History== [[File:10.12.12CharlesBrownsteinByLuigiNovi8.jpg|thumb|left|CBLDF Executive Director Charles Brownstein speaking at the 2012 [[New York Comic Con]]]] The Comic Book Legal Defense Fund began as a means to pay for the legal defense of ''Friendly Frank's'' comic shop manager Michael Correa, who was arrested in 1986 on charges of distributing obscenity.<ref>Thompson, Maggie. [http://www.cbgxtra.com/default.aspx?tabid=42&view=topic&forumid=34&postid=6606 "April 21, 1954: Mr. Gaines Goes to Washington," "The 1900s: 10 biggest events from 100 years in comics,"] CBGXtra.com (Dec. 12, 2005).</ref> The comic books deemed obscene were ''[[Omaha the Cat Dancer]]'', ''The Bodyssey'', ''[[Weirdo (magazine)|Weirdo]]'', and ''Bizarre Sex''. [[Kitchen Sink Press]] released an art portfolio of pieces donated by comics artists; proceeds were donated to Correa's defense. First amendment attorney [[Burton Joseph]] defended ''Friendly Frank's'' and ultimately had the conviction overturned. [[Denis Kitchen]] officially incorporated the CBLDF in 1990 as a non-profit charitable organization with capital left over from Correa's defense fund, and Burton Joseph became their legal counsel in 1996. Since then the Fund and Burton Joseph have provided advice and legal assistance in many cases and incidents.<ref>[http://www.icv2.com/articles/news/17202.html "R.I.P. Burton Joseph, First Amendment Attorney"] IC<sub>v</sub>2 (4 April 2010), accessed 4 April 2010</ref> In 1991 the CBLDF got honoured by the [[List of Eisner Award winners#Bob Clampett Humanitarian Award|Bob Clampett Humanitarian Award]].
The Fund publishes a quarterly newsletter called ''Busted! : the official newsletter of the Comic Book Legal Defense Fund''. {{OCLC|41042960}}
On September 29, 2011, it was announced that the CBLDF acquired intellectual property rights of the [[Comics Code Authority]] seal from the now-defunct [[Comics Magazine Association of America]]; the sale coincided with [[Banned Books Week]]. The CBLDF intends to use the seal in merchandise through licensing agreements, with proceeds from the licenses benefitting the CBLDF.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cbldf.org/homepage/cbldf-receives-comics-code-authority-seal-of-approval/|title=CBLDF Receives Comics Code Authority Seal of Approval - Comic Book Legal Defense Fund|website=Cbldf.org|accessdate=12 January 2018}}</ref>
The CBLDF works independently and with coalitions to defend against unconstitutional legislation.<ref name="cbldf.org">{{cite web|url=http://cbldf.org/about-2/|title=About - Comic Book Legal Defense Fund|website=Cbldf.org|accessdate=12 January 2018}}</ref> CBLDF works with the Media Coalition, along with: [[American Booksellers Foundation for Free Expression|The American Booksellers for Free Expression Group at ABA]], [[Association of American Publishers|Association of American Publishers, Inc.]], [[Authors Guild]], [[Entertainment Software Association]], [[Freedom to Read Foundation]], [[Motion Picture Association of America|Motion Picture Association of America, Inc]]., and [[Recording Industry Association of America|Recording Industry Association of America, Inc.]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mediacoalition.org/about/|title=ABOUT - mediacoalition|website=Mediacoalition.org|accessdate=12 January 2018}}</ref> They were active plaintiffs against internet filters in libraries<ref name="cbldf.org"/> and more recently in 2012, a Utah bill that wanted to censor internet speech, which the CBLDF was able to help stop.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cbldf.org/2012/05/free-speech-advocates-score-victory-in-utah/|title=Free Speech Advocates Score Victory in Utah - Comic Book Legal Defense Fund|website=Cbldf.org|accessdate=12 January 2018}}</ref>
Since 2008 the CBLDF has published an annual comic book, ''The CBLDF Liberty Annual'', to which many major artists and writers, including [[J. Michael Straczynski]], [[Garth Ennis]], and [[Richard Corben]], have contributed.
==Programs== The CBLDF creates toolkits that are available for librarians and others to use on the website.<ref name="cbldf.org"/> They also give lectures and presentations "at comic book and anime conventions, library and book trade conferences, universities, and symposiums in the United States and around the world."<ref name="cbldf.org"/>
==Notable cases== *1986: Michael Correa, store manager at Friendly Frank's, a comic store in [[Lansing, Illinois]], was charged with possession and sale of obscene material, after over 100 comic books were seized, including copies of ''[[Omaha the Cat Dancer]]'', and ''[[Verotika]]''. He was convicted, but the conviction was overturned on appeal. Funds donated to the appeal exceeded costs, and the remainder went towards founding the CBLDF.<ref>Morrisard, James A. (March 4, 1998). [http://www.citypaper.com/arts/story.asp?id=5032 "Comics Relief - CBLDF Comes to Legal Aid of Comic-Book Artists, Publishers, and Sellers"]. ''[[Baltimore City Paper]]''.</ref> *1991: Comic artist [[Paul Mavrides]] protested against a resolution by the State of California to levy a sales tax on comic strips and comic books. He challenged the law in court, with assistance from the CBLDF, arguing that the comic strip is a communications medium that should be classed with books, magazines, and newspapers (which are not subject to sales taxes due to [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] provisions).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.subgenius.com/bigfist/Vreedeez/X0005_Mavrides_Case_Could_.html|title=Mavrides Case Could Make or Break California Comics Publishing|website=Subgenius.com|accessdate=12 January 2018}}</ref> In 1997, a ruling in Mavrides' favor was handed down by the California State Board of Equalization. *1994: [[Florida]]-based underground comic book artist [[Mike Diana]] was convicted in March for obscenity stemming from his self-published ''[[Boiled Angel]]''. He was sentenced to three years probation, 1248 hours of community service, a $3000 fine, was banned from having contact with minors, and was forced to undergo a journalistic ethics course and a psychiatric evaluation at his own expense. After relocating to [[New York City]] to serve out his sentence, he performs his community service hours—working for the Comic Book Legal Defense Fund.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cbldf.org/casefiles/diana.shtml |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2005-09-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20001121064500/http://www.cbldf.org/casefiles/diana.shtml |archivedate=2000-11-21 |df= }}</ref> *2000: Comic book artist [[Kieron Dwyer]] was sued by [[Starbucks]] Coffee for parodying their famous mermaid logo within his comic book ''Lowest Common Denominator.'' Although the judge ruled that Starbucks could not sue a parody and the case settled out of court, Dwyer was forced to comply with the ruling that he could no longer use his logo for its confusing similarity to that of Starbucks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbldf.org/pr/001130-starbucks.shtml |title=Cartoonist Kieron Dwyer Sued By Starbucks |accessdate=2016-11-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010204153200/http://www.cbldf.org/pr/001130-starbucks.shtml |archivedate=2001-02-04}}</ref> *2002: The [[Castillo v. Texas]] case centered around Jesus Castillo, an employee of a comic book store in [[Dallas, Texas]], who charged with two counts of "display of obscenity", and convicted for one, after selling adult comics to an adult undercover police officer. *2005: [[Rome, Georgia]] comics retailer [[Gordon Lee (comic store owner)|Gordon Lee]] was charged with distributing obscene material to a minor, after a child obtained an anthology comic containing brief nudity in an excerpt of ''[[The Salon (comics)|The Salon]]'' on [[Halloween]]. A mistrial was called in 2007, and the case was finally dismissed in April 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cbldf.org/pr/archives/000310.shtml |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-12-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070204081048/http://www.cbldf.org/pr/archives/000310.shtml |archivedate=2007-02-04 |df= }}</ref><ref name="nytimes">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/06/books/06gust.html |title=When Picasso Went Down To Georgia |author=George Gene Gustines |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=May 6, 2007 |accessdate=March 8, 2010}}</ref> *2008: [[United States v. Handley]]; A 38-year-old Iowa comic collector named Christopher Handley was prosecuted under obscenity charges. The defense was led by Eric Chase, who was assisted by the CBLDF as a consultant.<ref>[http://www.cbldf.org/pr/archives/000372.shtml CBLDF To Serve As Special Consultant In PROTECT Act Manga Case] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081013031340/http://www.cbldf.org/pr/archives/000372.shtml |date=2008-10-13 }} October 9, 2008</ref><ref>[http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2008-10-10/iowa-collector-charged-for-allegedly-obscene-manga Iowa Collector Charged for Allegedly Obscene Manga] October 10, 2008</ref> *2010: R. v. Matheson; 27 year old Ryan Matheson was flying from the United States to Canada when customs officials searched his personal belongings and found manga on his computer, which the officer considered to be child pornography. Brandon has been charged with the possession and importation of "child pornography" by the Canadian government. The CBLDF assisted by raising funds for the case. The Crown has since withdrawn all criminal charges.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cbldf.org/about-us/case-files/cbldf-case-files/cbldf-case-files-canada-customs-case/|title=CBLDF Case Files – R. v. Matheson - Comic Book Legal Defense Fund|website=Cbldf.org|accessdate=12 January 2018}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Comic Legends Legal Defense Fund]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== *[http://www.citypaper.com/arts/story.asp?id=5032 Baltimore City Paper - CBLDF Comes to Legal Aid of Comic-Book Artists, Publishers, and Sellers]. Accessed January 19, 2006 *{{webarchive |url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20041221024840/http://www.firstamendmentcenter.org/speech/arts/topic.aspx?topic=comix |title=First Amendment Center |date=2004-12-21}}. Accessed January 19, 2006
==External links== {{commons category}} *{{official website|http://www.cbldf.org}} *[http://www.wildriverreview.com/4/worldvoices-neilgaiman.php Neil Gaiman talks about involvement with the Fund]
[[Category:Freedom of expression organizations]] [[Category:Legal advocacy organizations in the United States]] [[Category:Comics-related organizations]] [[Category:Bob Clampett Humanitarian Award winners]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1986]]

[[File:Pieter Bruegel II-Combat de Carnaval et Careme IMG 1463.JPG|thumb|Carnival and debauchery is also a running theme in the paintings of [[Pieter Bruegel the Elder]], painted during the 16th century.]] The '''Culture of Popular Laughter''' is a historical-[[anthropology|anthropological]] theory devised by the literary critic [[Mikhail Bakhtin]], first published in the book ''[[Rabelais and His World]]'', based on observations of [[popular culture]] in the [[Renaissance]]. Bakhtin analysed [[François Rabelais]]' book ''[[Gargantua and Pantagruel]]'' and its portrayals of "grotesque realism" (i.e. celebrations of [[Maslow's hierarchy of needs|primary needs]]) and [[carnival]] in which [[Norm (social)|social norms]] were subverted.
The Culture of Popular Laughter combines two literary ideas developed by Bakhtin in the same work: the idea of "[[Grotesque body]]" and "[[Carnivalesque]]" debauchery. It is distinguished from each, however, by its applications outside literary theory.
==Carnivalesque== {{main|Carnivalesque}} The idea of "[[Carnivalesque]]" was also created by Bakhtin and forms part of his wider theory of Popular Laughter. He argued that, during times of carnival such as the [[Feast of Fools]], social norms were deliberately turned upside-down. The carnival then became a form of [[Safety-valve institution]], which served a [[Structural functionalism|Structural-functionalist]] role to temporarily release stresses in the contemporary social system.<ref>{{cite book|last=Klaniczay|first=Gábor|title=The Uses of Supernatural Power: the Transformation of Popular Religion in Medieval and Early-modern Europe|year=1990|publisher=Princeton University Press|location=Princeton, N.J.|isbn=0691073775|page=12}}</ref> Bakhtin, however, argued that this form of system was "formalized" in the culture of the period as "popular laughter".
===Scope and influence=== The historian Gábor Klaniczay argued that the Culture of Popular Laughter stretched through all echelons of society and was certainly not restricted to the peasantry.<ref>{{cite book|last=Klaniczay|first=Gábor|title=The Uses of Supernatural Power: the Transformation of Popular Religion in Medieval and Early-modern Europe|year=1990|publisher=Princeton University Press|location=Princeton, N.J.|isbn=0691073775|page=17}}</ref> Bakhtin's theory has also been credited with bringing about a scholarly reassessement of the importance of popular culture in history.<ref>{{cite book|last=Klaniczay|first=Gábor|title=The Uses of Supernatural Power: the Transformation of Popular Religion in Medieval and Early-modern Europe|year=1990|publisher=Princeton University Press|location=Princeton, N.J.|isbn=0691073775|page=24}}</ref>
==Examples== The Culture of Popular Laughter was originally formulated based on the writings of Rabelais, but has also been applied in the interpretation of peasant scenes painted by [[Pieter Bruegel the Elder]] and [[Pieter Bruegel the Elder#Family tree|his descendants]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Gibson|first=Walter S.|title=Pieter Bruegel and the Art of Laughter|year=2006|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley|isbn=0520245210|page=33|edition=1st}}</ref> The example has also been applied to Japanese society.<ref>{{cite book|last=de Wil|first=Theodore|title=Sources of Japanese tradition from earliest times-1600|year=2001|publisher=Columbia University Press|location=New York|isbn=0231121393|page=471|edition=2nd|volume=1|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
[[Category:Renaissance]] [[Category:Grotesque]] [[Category:Carnivals]] [[Category:Popular culture studies]] [[Category:Social anthropology]] [[Category:Laughter]] [[Category:Functionalism (social theory)]] [[Category:Works about festivals]]

[[Mandarin Chinese|Mandarin]] (Season 2 and 3)
[[English language|English]] | network = [[KBS1]] | first_run = | first_aired = {{start date|2006|11|24}} | last_aired = 2016 | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | num_seasons = 3 | num_episodes = 65 | website = http://www.kbs.co.kr/2tv/sisa/curucuru/index.html }} {{Infobox Korean name| | title = Curucuru and Friends | hangul = {{linktext|꾸|루|꾸|루|와}} {{linktext|친|구|들}} | hanja = | rr = Kkurukkuruwa Chingudeul | mr = Kkurukkuruwa Ch'ingutŭl }} '''''Curucuru and Friends''''' ({{ko-hhrm|꾸루꾸루와 친구들||Kkurukkuruwa Chingudeul}}; also known as '''''Tales of Greenery''''' or '''''The Family of Greenwood''''' ({{zh|s=绿树林家族|p=Lǜ shù lín jiāzú}})) is a 2006 [[South Korea|Korean]]-[[China|Chinese]] [[Stop Motion]] series animated by [[Ffango Entertoyment]] (Now Comma Studios), primarily aimed for [[Preschool]]ers. It is officially Ffango's first original stop motion animated series,http://blog.naver.com/PostView.nhn?blogId=ffango&logNo=110070223874 directed by Jung Hye-On and written by both Yi Jeong-Geun and Jang Eun-Ju with character designs by Jin Hyo-Jung.{{cite web|url=http://blog.naver.com/jinit79/20193831055|title=TwinkleJini|publisher=Naver |date=2013-08-15|accessdate=2014-07-12}} The first season is aired [[KBS1]] from November 24, 2006 to February 16, 2007, with a total of 13 episodes. A second season, made after the rights transfer, is then produced and aired in [[China]], produced in a joint collaboration between [[Zhejiang Chinese Cartoon Co.]] and [[Beijing Pan Gaowen media Ltd]] from September 2013 to February 2014, with a total count of 26 episodes. A movie sequel titled '''''Curucuru and Friends: The Rainbow Tree Forest''''' ({{ko-hhrm|꾸루꾸루와 친구들: 무지개 나무의 비밀||Kkurukkuruwa Chingudeul: mujigae namuui bimil}}) was released on Korean theaters on November 19, 2015.http://www.gukjenews.com/news/articleView.html?idxno=364616 A third season of the series was released in 2016. In 2017, based on the superheroes character series crossover were created in the original series, which are published by Stone Comics Entertainment - [[CJ ENM]] comic book and film franchise owner by [[CJ Group]] ==Story== ===Season 1=== The story is set in a village called Green Forest Village, where is inhabited by friendly animals. The story were focused on 5 special animal friends whose friendship binds them together, Koori: A brown [[raccoon]] boy and an aspiring inventor, Pinpin: A blue and white [[giant panda]] boy and a warm hearted artist, Lalla: a pink [[Tabby|Tabby cat]] girl and an aspiring musician who wishes to be a princess, Toto: a purple [[bat]] boy who wants to be a pilot and fly and lastly; Curucuru, a [[brown bear]] boy who likes to cook. All of them venture through several adventures in the forest and town, making exciting and marvelous stories and also getting in and out of trouble as they learn valuable lessons in life and things around them. ===Season 2-3=== Around the second season, the story revolves around the kids trying to foil the troublemaking duo Archie, a gray [[jackrabbit]] boy and Dangdang, a brown monkey boy who were trying to cause trouble in the Green Forest Village. ===The Rainbow Tree Forest=== The movie takes place between Seasons 1 and 2. The Green Forest Village hosts a festival in celebration of the 1000th anniversary of the large tree growing in the middle of the village. While Curucuru and his friends are helping in the festival, they learned that tree's vitality is due to a legendary item call the Pingya, which gives it Eternal Love and Life. But in the midst of the festival, a bunch of Pirate Hyenas came to the village and stole the legendary item, causing the tree to wilt. Now it's up to Curucuru and his pals to get it back from the pirates, before things can go worse. But amidst the actual troubles they face, the kids also encounter a strange Tiger child, who is connected to the incident. ===Season 4=== After reclaiming all of the legendary pirates, connected and went back to Green Forest Village. The movie takes place between Seasons 1 and 2. Around the third season, the story revolves around the Curucuru and his friends live peacefully until two mysterious people, Calps and Coops who are wolf and fox hunters working for their corrupt leadership Lord Big Boss, arrive at world to capture him and his friends and sell them to the black market. Curucuru and his friends team up to foil their plans, as well as save the Green Forest Village. ==Cast== '''Curucuru''' ({{ko-hhrm|꾸루꾸루||Kkurukkuru}}) : Voiced by: Choe Mun-Ja (Season 1), [[Jo Hyeon-jeong]] (Movie and Season 4) The series's main protagonist, Curucuru is a [[brown bear]] boy who likes to cook but sometimes has tendencies to get hungry and eat anything. Despite being big, he's very lazy, sleepy and sometimes lack courage and tenacity but despite all of these, he is always supportive to all of his friends. He is also a very slow runner and has problems with his weight. He is best friends with Toto. '''Koori''' ({{ko-hhrm|쿠리||Kuri}}) : Voiced by: Jeon Tae-Yeol (Season 1), [[Bak Sin-hee]] (Movie and Season 4) Koori is a brown [[raccoon]] boy who is well known as the town's aspiring inventor. Usually prideful, smart and always brags, his creations were a hit and miss when it comes to success. Somehow he never gives up on inventing and impressing his friends. He has a little sister named Haru and is also the oldest of the two siblings. '''Lalla''' ({{ko-hhrm|랄라||Lalla}}) : Voiced by: Hong Yeong-Lan (Season 1), [[Lee So-eun]] (Movie and Season 4) Lalla is a pink [[Tabby|Tabby cat]] girl and the only female member of the group, who is the village's aspiring singer. She likes to dance and perform but also doesn't want her private stuff to be touched. She's very posh, likes attention and likes to be pretty, but also very kind to her friends. She lives with her mother and shown to collect various types of dolls and cute stuff. '''Pinpin''' ({{ko-hhrm|핀핀||Pinpin}}) : Voiced by: Choe Jeong-Ho Pinpin is a blue and white [[giant panda]] boy who likes to paint and draw, considered as the Picasso of the Greenery Forest. He likes to paint and draw, thought sometimes has a hard time finding inspiration. He is very clam and also has a kind heart to everyone, thought also gets rather scared and saddened easily. He lives with his parents and often seeks advise to his grandfather, who lives near the lake. '''Toto''' ({{ko-hhrm|토토||Toto}}) : Voiced by: Gim Ok-Gyeong (Season 1), [[Yuri Seo]] (Movie and Season 4) Toto is a purple [[bat]] boy who wishes to fly and also likes to become a pilot. The youngest member of the group, he is very curious, inquisitive and also very adventurous. However, for these traits, he can be very mischievous and sometimes stubborn on things. Despite being a bat, he somehow can't fly due to the lack wings. He is best friends with Curucuru. '''Archie''' ({{zh|s=阿奇|p=Ā qí}}) :{{Anime voice|N/A}} One of the characters debuting in season 2, Archie is a light gray [[jackrabbit]] boy who causes trouble to the children in the Green Forest Village. He is always accompanied by Dandan on their schemes. '''Dangdang''' ({{zh|s=当当|p=Dāng Dāng}}) :{{Anime voice|N/A}} Also a character debuting in season 2, Dandan is a brown [[monkey]] boy who also causes trouble to the children in the Green Forest Village. He always adores Archie on building up schemes. ==Episodes== ===Season 1 (2006-2007)=== {|class="wikitable" style="width:100%; margin:auto; background:#FFF; table-layout:fixed;" |- style="border-bottom: 3px solid #92E500" ! style="width:3em;" | No. ! ===Season 3 (2016)=== ===Season 4 (2017)=== On [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]], 4 episodes have not been included in the English release. In 2018, Tales of Greenery (Curucuru and Friends) – Family of Forest is the US English adaptation of the 2005-2009 Korean stop-motion & flash animated series that has been airing since July 7, 2014 and has aired a total of 52 episodes as of 2015. Since February 1, 2016 the US adaptation airs bilingually in [[South Korea]] on [[Disney Channel Korea]]. As of June 12, 2016, broadcasts of new episodes in the US are currently on hiatus according to [[Bang Zoom! Entertainment]]. However, [[Disney XD]] began to rerun the existing dubbed episodes in March 2017 as a lead-in to its new weekday afternoon animated block. This dub takes many liberties from the original Korean version. Besides using the name changes that were used in Alt Korea's English adaptation of the original manga, other changes and edits have been made to make the show more relatable to an American audience, such as Korean text being replaced with English text on certain objects like signs and graded papers, items such as yen notes being replaced by US dollar bills, and the setting being changed from Seoul to a small town in the southern US state of North Carolina.’ {{Episode table |background=#2FB4E9 |overall= |season= |title= |accessdate= |director= |writer= |airdate= |episodes = {{Episode list OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2018|5|24}} | ShortSummary = | LineColor = 2FB4E9 }} }} ==Development== Originating as a pilot film in 2003, the series officially greenlited into an animated series in 2004 The series's development first began back in 2003 after the Ffango animation studio is renamed into Ffango Entertoyment. The series began as a pilot film selected by the [[Korea Creative Content Agency]] and [[Seoul Movie]] took interest in the series which got officially greenlited in 2004, with Government Donation and support by the [[Gyeonggi Digital Content Agency]].http://www.kocca.kr/eng/industry/content/1309443_2026.html In 2005, the series became one of KOCCA's Star Project and aired a year later on [[Korean Broadcasting System]] in November 24, 2006. The series was also broadcast in mainland [[China]] by [[China Central Television]] in 2008 under the name '''''The Family of Greenwood'''''. The second season is aired from September 2013 to February 2014http://thinkinghand.co.kr/?portfolio=tales-of-greenery-season-2-2 with support from both the [[China Film Group]] and [[Alpha Group Company|Guangdong Alpha Animation & Culture Co., Ltd.]] The series is animated using customized [[ball joint]]ed puppets created by Thinking Hand Creative Studiohttp://thinkinghand.co.kr/?portfolio=2648 and Darak Workshophttp://julie419en.cafe24.com/Front/Mall/?url=Comintro& with several expression faces made for each characters. Production took about 3 years total, making the puppets, backgrounds and scripts for each episode. Each scene and episode were shot using 100 [[Canon EOS-1D Mark II]] Stop Motion Control Cameras.http://blog.naver.com/PostList.nhn?blogId=ffango&from=postList&categoryNo=1&parentCategoryNo=1 An official musical is also made for the series, which run in 2007 to 2011. However, in 2009 due to financial issues and company restructuring, the series rights is sold to [[China Film Group]]. In 2011, KOCCA stated that a theatrical film is currently in development alongside the second season.http://thinkinghand.co.kr/?portfolio=tales-of-greenery-season-2 JeDae Moon stated that "Investment for the season 2 is ongoing in China and more success is expected. We believe we stepped off on the right foot with KOCCA's support.".http://www.hancinema.net/best-korean-animation-releases-at-3-000-theaters-in-china-33676.html This is also the first time that KOCCA's OSMU ([[One Source Multi-Use]]) model has been taken up in a collaborative venture between Korea and China.http://www.creativetransformations.asia/2012/12/korean-soft-powers-animated-ambitions-in-china/ A second season of the series was in the works in 2012 and aired between September 2013 to February 2014. [[Iconix Entertainment]] currently handles the worldwide distribution rights of the series while [[Alpha Group Company]] distributes the series inside Mainland China after the rights transfer. Officially developed back in 2016, the series was created to educate children about protection and preservation of the environment and encourages parents and their children to appreciate friendship, harmony, honesty and courage. Tales of Greenery (Curucuru & Friends) based on the stop-motion, toyline, and superheroes of the same name film franchise, produced by Korean comics book and animated publisher by [[Haksan Publishing]] and Ffango Entertoyment animated series was first published in December 2017 in six different magazines. A based on the superheroes character series crossover were created in the original series, which are published by Stone Comics Entertainment - [[CJ ENM]] comic book and film franchise owner by [[CJ Group]] now currently owns the license for the series's distribution in [[South Korea]], [[Japan]] and [[America]]. [[CJ ENM Corporation]] currently handles the worldwide distribution rights of the series while under licensing by International Media Partners Development Company global distributes the series inside [[United States]], [[UK]], [[Canada]], [[Brazil]], [[France]], [[Germany]], [[Mexico]], [[Belgium]], [[Thailand]], [[China]], [[Malaysia]], [[Vietnam]], [[Japan]] & [[Indonesia]] after the rights transfer. The series began as a pilot film selected by the [[Korea Creative Content Agency]] and [[Seoul Movie]] took interest in the series which got officially greenlited in 2014, with [[Government Donation]] and support by the [[Gyeonggi Digital Content Agency]]. In 2015, the series became one of KOCCA's Star Project and aired a year later on [[Korean Broadcasting System]] in November 24, 2016. IMPDC Licensing picked up the license to dub the first season with new distribution done by [[VIZ Media]] & [[Showcase Entertainment]] and flash-animation done [[Studio Vandal]], [[nSac Film Partners]], [[Sunwoo Entertainment]], [[Sim-ei Entertainment]], [[Magic Image Co., Ltd.]], and [[MICO Animation Studio. Ltd]]. It was English dubbing studio post-production [[Bang Zoom! Entertainment]]. The dub premiered on July 1, 2015 and ended on December 23, 2015 and received mostly mixed to negative reviews from critics. In 2013, an edited English dub distributed by [[CJ ENM]] [[Tooniverse]] & [[Korean Broadcasting System]] aired on [[ABC3]] & [[Disney XD]] in the United States started on July 7, 2014. In Epcot, Curucuru and Friends toys are on the Korean shop. On August 17, 2015, another English dubbed version distributed by Luk Internacional began broadcasting on [[Boomerang UK]]. In 2015, based on the comic book & superheroes team media film franchise is the US English adaptation of the 2006 Korean stop-motion and animated children's television series that has been airing since July 7, 2014 and has aired a total of season 2, 54 episodes as of 2015. Since February 1, 2016 the US adaptation airs bilingually in South Korea on [[Disney Channel Korea]]. As of June 12, 2016, broadcasts of new episodes in the US are currently on hiatus according to [[Bang Zoom! Entertainment]]. However, [[Disney XD]] began to rerun the existing dubbed episodes in March 2017 as a lead-in to its new weekday afternoon animated block. [[Haksan Publishing]] currently handles the worldwide distribution rights of the series while comic book publisher [[Manhwa]] and [[webtoons]] ==Production== Curucuru & Friends was stop-motion animated by [[Ffango Entertoyment]] and [[Seoul Movie]] for season 1, [[Zhejiang Chinese Cartoon Co.]] and [[Beijing Pan Gaowen media Ltd]] for season 2-3 and Flash-animated by [[Studio Vandal]], [[nSac Film Partners]], [[Sunwoo Entertainment]], [[Sim-ei Entertainment]], [[Magic Image Co., Ltd.]], and [[MICO Animation Studio. Ltd]] for season 4. The series lasted for four seasons and 41 episodes. ==Reception== Total Licensing Magazine stated that the series "is not didactic in its approach but, through animation in conveys originality, sociality and propriety in a way to interest the children."http://www.nxtbook.com/dal/totallicensing/winter2007/index.php?startid=52 ===Awards=== The First season of the series won Grand Prize in the 2003 [[Seoul International Cartoon and Animation Festival]], won best animation in the Gyeonggi Digital Art Center in 2004 and the 13th Korean Animation Awards for best animation in 2007. The series received the Golden Monkey Award in the 8th China International Animation Festival in 2012. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.kbs.co.kr/2tv/sisa/curucuru/index.html Official KBS Website (Korean)] * [http://www.kmdb.or.kr/movie/md_basic.asp?nation=K&p_dataid=10530 Curucuru and Friends in the Korean Movie Database] [[Category:Manhwa titles]] [[Category:South Korean animation]] [[Category:2000s South Korean television series]] [[Category:Stop-motion animated television series]] [[Category:South Korean animated television series]] [[Category:2013 Chinese television series debuts]] [[Category:2014 Chinese television series endings]] [[Category:Chinese animated television series]] [[Category:2000s animated television series]] [[Category:Chinese animated television programs featuring anthropomorphic characters]] [[Category:Preschool education television series]] [[Category:Korean Broadcasting System television programmes]]

A '''cut-out score''' or '''cutout score''' is a [[Sheet music|musical score]] in which measures with [[rest (music)|rests]] are simply omitted, and no rests of any kind are used. Cut-out scores are mostly used for proportional notation scores, such as Penderecki's ''[[Threnody to the Victims of Hiroshima]]''. "Proponents of this arrangement argue that it dispenses with needless clutter on the score page," while "others maintain that not enough is gained by this format to justify the extra effort in setting up the score."<ref>Kennan & Grantham (1990): 337</ref>
Cut-out scores can be created with any full-featured [[scorewriter]], such as Finale or Sibelius. Instead of extracting parts, all the players are given the score.
<!--this image displayed wider than 400px for clarity--> [[Image:CutOutScoreXamp.png]]

{{for|the upcoming TV series|Deadly Class (TV series)}} {{Infobox comic book title | image = Deadly_Class_1_by_Rick_Remender,_cover_art_by_Wesley_Craig,_January_2014.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Cover art for ''Deadly Class'' #1. Art by Wesley Craig.
| schedule = Monthly | format = | genre = Action-thriller | limited = | ongoing = y | 1shot = | Action/Crime = y | publisher = [[Image Comics]] | date = January 22, 2014 – present | startmo = January | startyr = 2014 | endmo = | endyr = | issues = 35 | main_char_team = | issn = | writers = [[Rick Remender]] | artists = Wesley Craig | pencillers = | inkers = | letterers = Rus Wooton | colorists = [[Lee Loughridge]] | editors = Sebastian Girner | creative_team_month = | creative_team_year = | creators = [[Rick Remender]] | TPB = SC Vol. 1 | ISBN = 978-1632150035 | TPB2 = SC Vol. 2 | ISBN2 = 978-1632152220 | TPB3 = SC Vol. 3 | ISBN3 = 978-1632154767 | TPB4 = SC Vol. 4 | ISBN4 = 978-1632157188 | TPB5 = SC Vol. 5 | ISBN5 = 978-1534300552 | TPB6 = SC Vol. 6 | ISBN6 = 978-1534302471 | TPB7 = HC Vol. 1 | ISBN7 = 978-1632156648 | subcat = | altcat = | sort = Deadly Class (comic book) | addpubcat# = | nonUS = }} '''''Deadly Class''''' is an [[Action fiction|action]] [[genre]] [[American comic book]] series written by [[Rick Remender]], illustrated by Wesley Craig, colored by [[Lee Loughridge]], and lettered by Rus Wooton. ''Deadly Class'' follows students enrolled at King's Dominion Atelier of the Deadly Arts, a secret high school in [[San Francisco]], as they train to become the next generation of top assassins for crime families across the globe. [[Image Comics]] has published ''Deadly Class'' on a mostly monthly basis since the first issue was released on January 22, 2014.{{cite web|url=https://imagecomics.com/comics/releases/deadly-class-1|title=Deadly Class #1|date=June 15, 2017|publisher=Image Comics|accessdate=June 15, 2017}} ==Plot== The first issues of ''Deadly Class'' focus on the story of teenage orphan Marcus Lopez Arguello as he transitions from living on the streets to being enrolled into a school of assassins. The academy, run by Master Lin, is composed of children of mob bosses and mass murderers, learning the same trade as their parents.{{cite web|url=https://comicsverse.com/deadly-class/|title=DEADLY CLASS: The Making of a Murderer|last=Danoff|first=Mara|date=April 20, 2017|website=Comicverse|accessdate=June 15, 2017}} Marcus's decision to attend the school is one of the only decisions he gets to make for himself throughout the arc and history. His entire life has been composed of unfortunate events, each leaving him further ostracized from humanity. Marcus's lack of residence is primarily due to both of his parents dying in a horrible accident when he was young. This resulted in Marcus being placed into an orphanage, in which the head of the house required his manual labor for him to retain residence. This continued degradation of his sanity through the abuse by the hands of his roommates and guardians eventually drives him to committing a massive act of violence. ''Deadly Class'' then continues to follow the stories of the individuals enrolled in the academy and many of their eventual downfalls.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbr.com/remender-breaks-down-the-aftermath-of-deadly-class-freshmen-finals/|title=Remender Breaks Down the Aftermath of "Deadly Class'" Freshmen Finals|last=Richards|first=Dave|date=June 6, 2016|website=Comic Book Resources|accessdate=June 15, 2017}} ==Characters== '''Main characters''' *'''Marcus Lopez Arguello''' is the newest addition to King's Dominion. Plagued by tragedy and trauma, Marcus still finds himself an outcast at the school in regards to both the students and the teachers. *'''Saya Kuroki''' is the leader of the Kuroki Syndicate at King's Dominion. Her preferred weapon is a katana, which was passed down through her family. *'''Willie Lewis''' is a member of the Final World Order (F.W.O.) at King's Dominion and is one of Marcus' best friends. Willie is a sharpshooter who specializes in firearms. *'''Maria Esperanza Salazar''' is Marcus' girlfriend; a member of the Soto Vatos and Chico's former girlfriend. Maria's preferred weapons are bladed fans, and she is often seen adorned in Dia Los Muertos attire. *'''Master Lin''' is the ruthless headmaster of King's Dominion. *'''Viktor''' is a Russian brute who is the son of Joseph Stalin's personal assassin. Viktor utilizes his brute strength to overwhelm his opponents. *'''Petra Yolga''' is a goth girl who comes from a death cult. Petra specializes in poison, and gained honors in a class because of this. *'''Shabnam''' is a portly, nerdy boy who is Marcus's former roommate. Being the son of a wealthy banker, Shabnam uses his intellect and wit to strategically win battles. *'''Brandy Lynn''' is a Southern belle, and is known as the daughter of a famous neo-Nazi that assassinated dozens of civil rights activists. She is considered loud, racist, and a generic Confederate redneck. Brandy is adept at hand-to-hand combat, and has been seen utilizing various throws and grapples that make her a deadly opponent. *'''Billy Bennett''' is one of Marcus' best friends. He is kindly and soft, and needed help to kill his father. He seems friendly and funny, and he likes to skate. *'''Kelly "Grogda"''' is Shabnam's girlfriend who seduced Marcus at one point. *'''Shawn Parcel''' *'''Chico Salazar''' is the leader of the Soto Vatos, Maria's former boyfriend. *'''Kendall''' is Stephen's former boyfriend. He is one of the students who helped Marcus in the first issue. *'''Stephen''' is Kendall's former boyfriend. All he wants is to be one of the top students at King's Dominion. *'''Tosawhi''' is one of the new students. The others don't really like him but he doesn't seem to care. Like Billy, he's a skater. *'''Quan''' is one of the new students. He is both proud and arrogant. He attempted to hook up with Saya but finally gave up. *'''Helmut''' is one of the new students. He's German, loves metal, and also loves other "hardcore" things. *'''Zenzele''' is one of the new students. She's a bit weird and Brandy doesn't like her at all. She writes a lot of letters to her parents. ==Collected editions== {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan=4|Trade paperbacks |- ! Title !! Material collected !! Publication date !! ISBN |- |''Deadly Class'' – Vol. 1: Reagan Youth'' || ''Deadly Class'' #1–6 || July 16, 2014 || {{ISBNT|978-1632150035}} |- |''Deadly Class'' – Vol. 2: Kids of the Black Hole'' || ''Deadly Class'' #7–11 || March 18, 2015 || {{ISBNT|978-1632152220}} |- |''Deadly Class'' – Vol. 3: Snake Pit'' || ''Deadly Class'' #12–16 || October 7, 2015 || {{ISBNT|978-1632154767}} |- |''Deadly Class'' – Vol. 4: Die for Me'' || ''Deadly Class'' #17–21 || August 3, 2016 || {{ISBNT|978-1632157188}} |- |''Deadly Class'' – Vol. 5: Carousel'' || ''Deadly Class'' #22–26 || March 15, 2017 || {{ISBNT|978-1534300552}} |- |''Deadly Class'' – Vol. 6: This Is Not the End'' || ''Deadly Class'' #27–31 || December 26, 2017 || {{ISBNT|978-1534302471}} |- |''Deadly Class'' – Vol. 7: Love Like Blood'' || ''Deadly Class'' #32–35 || August 28, 2018 || {{ISBNT|978-1534306967}} |- |''Deadly Class'' – Vol. 8: Never Go Back'' || ''Deadly Class'' #36–40 || April 16, 2019 || {{ISBNT|978-1534310636}} |} {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan=5|Deluxe hardcovers |- ! Title !! Material collected !! Additional material || Publication date !! ISBN |- |''Deadly Class'' – Book One || ''Deadly Class'' #1–16 || | November 19, 2014 || {{ISBNT|978-1632156648}} |} ==In other media== ===Television adaptation=== {{Main|Deadly Class (TV series)}} Directors [[Russo brothers|Anthony and Joe Russo]] have signed on to produce a television series based on ''Deadly Class''. The [[Sony Pictures Television]]-produced adaptation has been optioned as a [[television pilot|pilot]] for the [[Syfy]] channel.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbr.com/sdcc-russo-brothers-to-produce-deadly-class-tv-series/|title=SDCC: Russo Brothers to Produce "Deadly Class" TV Series|last=Melrose|first=Kevin|date=July 21, 2016|website=Comic Book Resources|accessdate=June 15, 2017}} [[Benedict Wong]], [[Benjamin Wadsworth]], [[Lana Condor]], [[Michel Duval]] and [[María Gabriela de Faría]] are among the actors cast in main roles for the series.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/11/deadly-class-syfy-cast-comic-based-drama-pilot-1202205180/|title='Deadly Class': Syfy Sets Full Cast For Comic-Based Drama Pilot|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|first=Denise|last=Petski|date=November 9, 2017|accessdate=November 9, 2017}} On April 18, 2018, Syfy picked up the pilot to series.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2018/04/syfy-picks-up-series-deadly-class-drama-graphic-novel-russo-brothers-1202367038/|title=Syfy Picks Up To Series 'Deadly Class' Drama Based On Graphic Novel From The Russo Brothers|website=Deadline Hollywood|last1=Petski|first1=Denise|last2=Andreeva|first2=Nellie|date=April 18, 2018|accessdate=April 19, 2018}} The first episode will air on the 16 January on SyFy. ==See also== * ''[[Assassination Classroom]]'' * ''[[The Abashiri Family]]'' ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [https://imagecomics.com/comics/series/deadly-class Deadly Class] at [[Image Comics]] * [https://comicvine.gamespot.com/deadly-class/4050-71032/ Deadly Class] at [[Comic Vine]] * [http://comicbookdb.com/issue.php?ID=298017 Comic Book DB] [[Category:Image Comics titles]] [[Category:2014 comics debuts]] [[Category:Action comics]] [[Category:Comics by Rick Remender]] [[Category:School-themed comics]] [[Category:American comics]] [[Category:Comics set in the United States]] [[Category:Comics adapted into television series]] [[Category:Comics set in the 1980s]]

revision.comment: Corsair only purchased the Elgato Gaming division.
revision.text:
{{good article}} {{infobox brand | name = Elgato | logo = [[File:Logo Elgato Systems.png]] | image = | caption = | type = Consumer electronics (computer) | currentowner =[[Corsair Components]] (Elgato Gaming division only) | origin = | introduced = 2002 | discontinued = | related = | markets = | tagline = | website = [https://www.elgato.com/en elgato.com] | parentcompany = Corsair }} '''Elgato''' is a brand of consumer technology products. The manufacturer, also called Elgato, was founded in 1992 by Markus Fest and is headquartered in [[Munich, Germany]].<ref name="gigagioam">{{cite news|title=Elgato ends collaboration with Miglia|first=Eddie|last=Hargreaves|date=March 12, 2007|publisher=Giga Om|url=http://gigaom.com/2007/03/12/elgato-ends-collaboration-with-miglia/|accessdate=September 2, 2014}}</ref>
Elgato is best known for a line of video-recording products called EyeTV, which record video from over-the-air antennas, satellite TV, or mobile devices. The first EyeTV product was introduced in November 2002.
More recently{{When|date=July 2018}}, Elgato introduced a line of "smart" products, such as a [[Keychain#Key fob|key fob]] that tracks the user's distance from their car or purse and provides notifications to help them find it. In 2014, it introduced a home monitoring system called Eve, which provides alerts to users regarding things like air pressure, temperature and water use. Elgato also developed light bulbs that can respond to programming on a mobile device and respond to commands over Bluetooth and it produces two [[Thunderbolt (interface)|Thunderbolt]] products: a dock for MacBooks and an external hard drive. In May 2018, Elgato introduced Eve Aqua a HomeKit smart water controller.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://9to5mac.com/2018/05/29/eve-aqua-control-garden-hose-and-sprinklers-with-homekit/|title=Elgato launches Eve Aqua to let you control your garden hose and sprinklers with HomeKit|date=2018-05-29|work=9to5Mac|access-date=2018-06-27|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/circuitbreaker/2018/5/29/17404914/elgato-eve-aqua-smart-hose-controller-apple-ios-homekit|title=Elgato made a HomeKit-connected smart hose controller|work=The Verge|access-date=2018-06-27}}</ref>
On June 28th, 2018, [[Corsair Components]] acquired the gaming departments of Elgato, while Elgato's smart home team remains their own company and spun off as [[Eve Systems]].
==EyeTV==
===History=== The first EyeTV hardware device was introduced in November 2002.<ref name="ten">{{cite news|title=EyeTV 200|last=Seff|first=Jonathan|publisher=Macworld|date=July 2004}}</ref> It was a small [[USB]]-powered device that contained a cable tuner and hardware encoder in order to convert television video into an MPEG-1 format for watching on a computer.<ref name="five"/> It also had coaxial and RCA plugs to connect it with a VCR or camcorder.<ref name="five">{{cite news|first=Seff|last=Jonathan|title=EyeTV|date=November 2002|publisher=Macworld}}</ref> A 2002 article in Macworld said it was the "first step" in bridging computers and television, but at this point still had "some kinks".<ref name="five"/>
The next iteration was released in 2004 and called EyeTV 200. EyeTV 200 introduced a digital remote control and converted video programming into the higher-quality MPEG-2 format.<ref name="ten"/><ref name="thirteen">{{cite news|title=Devices Mimic TiVo -- Somewhat|newspaper=The Washington Post|first1=Daniel|last1=Greenberg|first2=Kevin|last2=Savetz|date=June 20, 2004|pp=F07|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A54095-2004Jun19.html|accessdate=August 12, 2014}}</ref> A [[Macworld]] review gave it 4 out of 5 stars for "very good" and emphasized the video quality and ease-of-use.<ref name="ten"/> A story in the ''[[Washington Post]]'' said it was more expensive than some alternatives, but worked on a Mac and had good-quality recordings.<ref name="thirteen"/> Also in 2004 the first EyeTV product for satellite television was introduced with the EyeTV 310,<ref>https://www.elgato.com/de/news/eyetv-310-fuer-paytv-mac</ref> which was later discontinued and replaced with EyeTV Sat.<ref name="register">{{cite news|title=Elgato EyeTV Sat|first=Cliff|last=Joseph|date=July 29, 2009|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2009/07/29/review_dvr_elgato_eyetv_sat/|newspaper=The Register}}</ref>
That same year a home media server called EyeHome was introduced. It had recording features similar to other EyeTV products, but was also intended for streaming a computer display to a television.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Mac Get Its Big Break: A Role in Home Theaters|date=May 27, 2004|newspaper=The New York Times|first=J. D.|last =Biersdorfer|accessdate=August 13, 2014|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/05/27/technology/circuits/27home.html}}</ref> It connected Mac computers and televisions that share the same home network. A review in Macworld gave it three stars or a "good" rating, saying that it was easy to install and worked well with Apple applications, but some aspects were quirky or frustrating.<ref>{{cite news|title=EyeHome|last=Seff|first=Jonathan|publisher=Macworld|date=July 2004}}</ref> ''Sound and Vision Magazine'' said it was "pretty darn cool" and an easy, inexpensive way to get media server functionality, though there were some user interface quirks. It gave the product an 89 out of 100 rating.<ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato EyeHome Digital Media Player and EyeTV 200 Tuner/DVR Page|newspaper=Sound and Vision Magazine|url=http://www.soundandvision.com/content/elgato-eyehome-digital-media-player-and-eyetv-200-tunerdvr-page-1|accessdate=August 12, 2014}}</ref>
By 2005, several other EyeTV products had been introduced, such as the EyeTV for DTT, the EyeTV EZ<ref>{{cite news|title=Digital TV in tiny package|first=Chris|last=Oaten|newspaper=Advertiser|date=November 19, 2005}}</ref> and the EyeTV Wonder.<ref>{{cite news|title=In Small Rooms, Fitting Many Functions: Tech Built for the Dorm|first=J.D.|last=Biersdorfer|date=August 3, 2005|newspaper=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/03/technology/techspecial3/03biersdorfer.html?_r=0|accessdate=August 12, 2014}}</ref> The EyeTV for DTT (digital terrestrial TV) is a small USB-powered device with an antenna for receiving free over-the-air television broadcasts. It received a 4 out of 5 rating in TechRadar.<ref>{{cite news|title=Do good things always come in small packages? Elgato thinks so...|publisher=TechRadar|first=Christopher|last=Phin|date=September 6, 2008|url=http://www.techradar.com/us/reviews/pc-mac/pc-components/tv-tuner-cards/elgato-eyetv-dtt-deluxe-457756/review|accessdate=August 14, 2014}}</ref> A review in ''The Register'' gave it an 85 percent rating.<ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato EyeTV DTT Mac digital TV tuner|first=Cliff|last=Joseph|date=November 26, 2008|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2008/11/26/review_tv_tuner_mac_elgato_eyetv_dtt/|newspaper=The Register}}</ref> The Eye TV Wonder was only available from July 2005 to January 2006, before being discontinued and replaced with the Eye TV EZ. The EZ was a basic, entry-level product with an analog tuner for watching TV on a Mac computer.<ref>{{cite news|title=EyeTV EZ|first=Anton|last=Linecker|publisher=Macworld|date=January 13, 2006|url=http://www.macworld.com/article/1048910/eyetvez.html|accessdate=August 14, 2014}}</ref>
In 2006, version 2.1 of the EyeTV software was introduced with a new user-interface, an integrated TV guide from [[TitanTV]]<ref>{{cite journal|title=New Products|journal=IEEE Multimedia|volume=13|issue=2|year=2006|pages=93–94|issn=1070-986X|doi=10.1109/MMUL.2006.38}}</ref> and compatibility with Apple remotes.<ref name="twenty">{{cite news|title=Elgato EyeTV 2.3 and equinux MediaCentral 2.1|last=Withers|first=Stephen|publisher=APC|date=November 2006|url=http://connection.ebscohost.com/c/product-reviews/22851456/elgato-eyetv-2-3-equinux-mediacentral-2-1|accessdate=August 14, 2014}}</ref> The interface was similar to that of other Apple products.<ref name="two"/> An article in Macworld praised the update and especially the new editing features, but said it had some quirks, such as a difficult-to-find Edit button.<ref name="two">{{cite news|title=EyeTV 2.1|first=Anton|last=Linecker| newspaper=Macworld|date=March 28, 2006|url=http://www.macworld.com/article/1050065/eyetv21.html}}</ref> Some of the iHome software, which plays video content from a computer onto a television, was released in 2006 as a universal binary.<ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato offers Universal Binary update for EyeHome|first=Peter|last=Cohen|newspaper=PC World|date=June 5, 2006|url=http://www.macworld.com/article/1051185/eyehome.html|accessdate=August 13, 2014}}</ref>
Version 2.4 of the EyeTV software was released in 2007 and added an export tool for Apple TV.<ref name="MachoverKasik2007">{{cite journal|last1=Machover|first1=Carl|last2=Kasik|first2=David J.|title=Tools and Products|journal=IEEE Computer Graphics and Applications|volume=27|issue=4|year=2007|pages=96–95|issn=0272-1716|doi=10.1109/MCG.2007.92}}</ref>
====Exit from the ATSC tuner market==== As of February 2015, Elgato no longer sells [[ATSC]] tuners. (ATSC is the digital television standard used in the United States, Canada, South Korea, Mexico and the Dominican Republic.) The Elgato web site explicitly declines to give a reason: "Elgato Technical Support is not able to comment on this business decision."<ref>As of February 2015, Elgato no longer offers TV tuner devices in North America https://help.elgato.com/customer/portal/articles/1858903-as-of-february-2015-elgato-no-longer-offers-tv-tuner-devices-in-north-america</ref>
In February 2016, [https://www.elgato.com/en/news/eyetv-february-2016 Elgato sells the EyeTV business to Geniatech Europe GmbH], a wholly owned subsidiary of Shenzhen Geniatech Inc., Ltd. Geniatech will take over the complete EyeTV product line. This company no longer sells the Turbo.264 HD software and reduced digital TV tuners to one model. No news about Thunderbolt products continuity.
===Current products===
====Over the air==== The EyeTV Diversity is a USB-powered device with dual [[Antenna tuner|tuner]]s for receiving over the air television broadcasts. The tuners can be used simultaneously for an optimized signal, or one tuner can be used to record a channel, while another is used to watch a separate show.<ref name="thirty"/> Diversity was first introduced in November 2006.<ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato unveils dual-tuner EyeTV Diversity USB stick in the UK|first=Darren|last=Murph|url=https://www.engadget.com/2006/11/07/elgato-unveils-dual-tuner-eyetv-diversity-usb-stick-in-the-uk/|publisher=Engadget|accessdate=August 12, 2014|date=November 7, 2006}}</ref> A driver in 2009 added compatibility with Windows 7.<ref name="thirty"/> A review in TechRadar gave EyeTV Diversity five out of five stars.<ref name="twentythree"/> [[PC Advisor]] and Pocket-Lint both gave it four out of five stars.<ref name="thirty">{{cite news|title=Elgato EyeTV Diversity review|first=Andrew|last=Harrison|newspaper=PC Advisor |date=December 15, 2009|url=http://www.pcadvisor.co.uk/reviews/pc-peripheral/3208742/elgato-eyetv-diversity-review/|accessdate=August 12, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato EyeTV Diversity dual-tuner DVB-T stick review|first=Stuart|last=Miles|date=February 11, 2009|accessdate=August 12, 2014|url=http://www.pocket-lint.com/review/70918-elgato-eyetv-diversity-dvb-tuner-review}}</ref>
[[File:Elgato EyeTV Hybrid.JPG|The EyeTV Hybrid|thumb|right]]EyeTV Hybrid, which can pick up digital or analog television broadcasts, was first released in early 2009.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hands On With Elgato’s EyeTV Hybrid|first=Charlie|last=Sorrel|date=March 10, 2009|url=https://www.wired.com/2009/03/hands-on-with-e/|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=August 14, 2014}}</ref> A CNET review said the device was easy and effective to use, but that buffering was often too slow to make watching live TV practical.<ref name="seven">{{cite news|accessdate=August 12, 2014|publisher=CNET|date=April 18, 2011|title=Elgato EyeTV Hybrid review: Elgato EyeTV Hybrid|url=http://www.cnet.com/products/elgato-eyetv-hybrid/}}</ref> Macworld said EyeTV's "core strength" was recording scheduled TV shows.<ref name="two"/> A review in ''PC Magazine'' gave the product 3.5 out of 5 stars. The review said it "works exceptionally well" but doesn't come with Windows software.<ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato EyeTV Hybrid|newspaper=PC Magazine|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2372891,00.asp|first=Will|last=Greenwald|accessdate=August 12, 2014}}</ref>
====Satellite==== In June 2010, the EyeTV HD product for recording [[High-definition television|high-definition]] cable and satellite programming was introduced.<ref name="forty"/> Because cable and satellite signals are encoded, the device must be connected to a tuner from a television provider. Then it provides remote controls, recording and DVR-functionality from a connected computer. A Macworld review gave the product four out of five stars.<ref name="forty">{{cite news|title=Elgato EyeTV HD|first=Jonathan|last=Seff|publisher=Macworld|date=June 11, 2010|url=http://www.macworld.com/article/1151922/eyetvhd_review.html|accessdate=August 12, 2014}}</ref> A review in ''Laptop Magazine'' gave EyeTV HD 3.5 out of 5 stars. It said the interface was intuitive and the video quality was good, but noted it was only compatible with Macs.<ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato EyeTV HD Review|first=Michael|last=Prospero|date=June 15, 2010|url=http://www.laptopmag.com/reviews/accessories/elgato-eyetv-hd#sthash.WZ6IqXkd.dpuf|newspaper=Laptop Magazine|accessdate=August 14, 2014}}</ref>
The EyeTV Netstream 4Sat has four satellite tuners, allowing four channels to be watched simultaneously from different devices. It was introduced in 2014.<ref name="fortyone">{{cite news|title=Elgato EyeTV Netstream 4Sat review: DVB-S2 HD TV Tuner|first=David|last=Denver|date=January 20, 2014|url=http://www.macworld.co.uk/review/mac-accessories/elgato-eyetv-netstream-4sat-review-3497900/|publisher=Macworld|accessdate=August 12, 2014}}</ref> A review in Macworld gave it 5 out of 5 stars. The review said Elgato had addressed some of the limitations of prior EyeTV satellite tuners like Netstream Sat/DTT.<ref name="fortyone"/> Pocket-Lint gave it 4.5 out of 5 stars<ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato EyeTV Netstream 4Sat review|first=Ian|last=Morris|url=http://www.pocket-lint.com/review/127555-elgato-eyetv-netstream-4sat-review|publisher=Pocket-Lint|accessdate=August 14, 2014|date=March 24, 2014}}</ref> CNET gave it five stars.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Elgato EyeTV Netstream DTT review|publisher=CNET|url=http://www.cnet.com/uk/products/elgato-eyetv-netstream-dtt/|accessdate=August 14, 2014|date=April 27, 2010}}</ref> The EyeTV Sat product, which receives free-to-air television, was introduced in Europe in late 2009.<ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato EyeTV Sat review|first=Adrian|last=Justins|date=October 20, 2009|publisher=TechRadar|url=http://www.techradar.com/us/reviews/pc-mac/pc-components/tv-tuner-cards/elgato-eyetv-sat-619309/review|accessdate=August 14, 2014}}</ref> ''The Register'' gave it an 80% rating, saying that it "works well" and that the documentation did not make it clear how to install the Apple and Windows versions of the software.<ref name="register"/>
====Software==== <!-- Commented out: [[File:EyeTV controller.png|thumb|right|The EyeTV digital remote|100px]] --> The EyeTV software was updated to version 3.0 in 2008. 3.0 made user interface improvements, such as being able to mark favorites or automatically record shows in a series. A review in TechRadar gave it 4.5 out of 5 stars. The review noted that EyeTV was the de facto software for TV and computer video integration and praised its new features, but said it was expensive when purchased separately.<ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato EyeTV 3 review: The best TV software just got better, but it’s not cheap|publisher=TechRadar|date=February 26, 2008|url=http://www.techradar.com/us/reviews/pc-mac/pc-components/tv-tuner-cards/elgato-eyetv-3-224285/review|accessdate=August 12, 2014}}</ref> A 2007 article in ''MacLife'' said their "top picks" for USB-powered tuners were those using the EyeTV software, such as the EyeTV hybrid or EyeTV 250.<ref name="Inc.2007"/> In addition to Elgato's EyeTV line of consumer devices, other brands such as Terratec and Miglia use the EyeTV software in their products through licensing agreements with Elgato.<ref name="twentythree">{{cite news|title=Elgato EyeTV Diversity review|date=January 10, 2007|url=http://www.techradar.com/us/reviews/pc-mac/pc-components/tv-tuner-cards/elgato-eyetv-diversity-39985/review|publisher=TechRadar|accessdate=August 12, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Inc.2007">{{cite book|first=Cathy|last=Lu|title=Mac Life|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xgIAAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA36|date=March 2007|publisher=Future US, Inc.|pages=36–37|id=19354010}}</ref>
====Mobile====
The EyeTV W was introduced in November 2013. It is a small 44 gram device that receives free digital over-the-air television broadcasts and makes it available to portable devices through a wireless hot spot.<ref name="twentyfive">{{cite news|title=EyeTV W Review: watch live television on iPhone and iPad|first=Lou|last=Hattersley |date= November 13, 2013|url=http://www.macworld.co.uk/review/home-entertainment/eyetv-w-review-watch-live-television-iphone-ipad-3488967/|publisher=Macworld}}</ref> A review in Macworld said it was portable, easy to use and had good battery life, but noted that users can't connect to other wi-fi networks and watch TV at the same time. It gave the product 4 out of 5 stars.<ref name="twentyfive"/> An EyeTV Mobile device for iPads was announced at the 2011 International Franchise Conference as the first tuner for the new [[Freeview (UK)|Freeview]] system in the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato EyeTV Mobile DTT/Freeview Television Tuner for iPad 2 Hands-on|date= September 2, 2011|accessdate=August 14, 2014|url=http://www.slashgear.com/elgato-eyetv-mobile-dttfreeview-television-tuner-for-ipad-2-hands-on-02176613/|publisher=Slashgear|first=Chris|last=Burns}}</ref>
[[File:EyeTV Micro.jpg|thumb|left|The EyeTV Micro product for Android devices]]Subsequently the EyeTV Mobile and EyeTV Micro products were released for iPhones and Android respectively.<ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato outs smaller EyeTV Mobile for iPhones and iPads, EyeTV Micro for Android|first=Jamie|last=Rigg|url=https://www.engadget.com/2012/08/31/elgato-outs-smaller-eyetv-mobile-and-new-eyetv-micro/|date=August 31, 2012|accessdate=August 14, 2014|publisher=Engadget}}</ref> The Micro and Mobile allow users to watch or record free over-the-air television programming from their smartphone.<ref name="name"/> Reviews of the mobile products ranged from 2 out of 5 stars by CNET<ref>{{cite news|first=|last=|publisher=CNET|url=http://www.cnet.com/products/elgato-eyetv-mobile/|accessdate=August 14, 2014|title=Live TV on your iPad comes up short on channels|date=December 3, 2012}}</ref> 4 out of 5 stars in Macworld<ref name="name">{{cite news|title=EyeTV Mobile review|first=Nick|last=Spence|publisher=Macworld|date=December 22, 2011|accessdate=August 14, 2014|url=http://www.pcadvisor.co.uk/reviews/gadget/3326730/eyetv-mobile-review/?tab=verdictTab#top}}</ref> and 3 out of 5 stars in ''PC Magazine''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato EyeTV Mobile|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2412451,00.asp|newspaper=PC Magazine|first=Eugene|last=Kim|accessdate=August 14, 2014}}</ref> There is also an EyeTV iPhone app that allows the user to watch their recorded shows on their iPhone, control their EyeTV recordings or watch live TV while connected to Wi-Fi.<ref name="LeVitus2010">{{cite book|author=Bob LeVitus|title=Incredible iPhone Apps For Dummies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4gyUgd9NWKwC&pg=PT54|date=January 19, 2010|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-0-470-63262-8|pages=54}}</ref> A compact version for laptops, the EyeTV GO, was introduced in May 2014.<ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato EyeTV Go|last=Hemphill|first=Kenny|publisher=MacUser|date=May 2014|url=http://connection.ebscohost.com/c/product-reviews/95441959/elgato-eyetv-go|accessdate=August 12, 2014}}</ref>
==Smart product line== {{See also|Eve Systems}}
===Smart key=== [[File:Elgato Smart Key hand.jpg|thumb|right|The Smart Key fob]] Elgato manufactures and markets a smart-key system. The system comes with a small 10-gram device that is placed on a key ring, in a purse, inside a car, or somewhere else.<ref name="nextweb"/> Then it communicates with an Elgato app on an iOS device. If it is set up for keys, the app will alert the user when they are 10 meters away from their keys, indicating that they may have forgotten them.<ref name="nextweb"/> It takes advantage of the "Smart Bluetooth" Apple implemented in iOS 7.<ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato's Smart Key uses iOS 7 Bluetooth Smart improvements to track your keys|date=October 11, 2013|first=Katie|last=Collins|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2013-10/11/elgato-smart-key|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=August 14, 2014}}</ref> A review in TheNextWeb said it was "money well spent" and worked "exactly as described", but that the beeping of the device could be louder and users will still need to supplement it with the Find my Phone app.<ref name="nextweb">{{cite news|title=The Elgato Smart Key taps Bluetooth LE to help find your keys and remember where your car’s parked|url=https://thenextweb.com/gadgets/2013/12/06/elgato-smart-key/|date=December 6, 2013|publisher=The Next Web|accessdate=August 14, 2014|first=Paul|last=Sawers}}</ref> A review in Macworld gave it 4 out of 5 stars.<ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato Smart Key Review: iPhone and iPad proximity location device tracker|date=December 10, 2013|first=Lou|last=Hattersley|url=http://www.macworld.co.uk/review/ios-accessories/elgato-smart-key-review-iphone-ipad-device-tracker-3493163/|accessdate=August 12, 2014}}</ref>
===Smart home=== In September 2014, Elgato announced a home monitoring system called Eve, which monitors a home's air pressure, water usage, temperature, air quality and other factors. Elgato said the product won't be available until the HomeKit software, which is expected to come with Apple iOS 8, is released.<ref name="dkajfhk">{{cite news|title=Elgato Eve will monitor the air in your house, works with iOS 8 HomeKit|first=Luke|last=Westaway |date=September 1, 2014|url=http://www.cnet.com/news/elgato-eve-monitors-the-air-in-your-house-works-with-ios-8-homekit/|publisher=CNET|accessdate=September 2, 2014}}</ref> It also introduced smart light bulbs, which communicate with iOS devices through Bluetooth and allow users to adjust home lighting from their mobile device.<ref name="dkajfhk"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato announces $50 Avea smart lightbulb and Eve smart home sensors|first=Michael|last=Gorman|url=https://www.engadget.com/2014/09/01/elgato-avea-smart-lightbulb-eve-smart-home-sensors/|publisher=Engadget|accessdate=September 2, 2014}}</ref>
===Smart power=== In late 2014, Elgato introduced the Smart Power battery backup for mobile devices. It communicates with the user's bluetooth-enabled device to provide notifications and calendar reminders when it needs to be charged.<ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato Smart Power: iPhone battery watches your calendar|date=September 1, 2014|url=http://www.slashgear.com/elgato-smart-power-iphone-battery-watches-your-calendar-01343804/|accessdate=September 9, 2014|publisher=Slashgear|first=Chris|last=Burns}}</ref>
==Thunderbolt==
===Thunderbolt dock=== [[File:Elgato Dock Back.jpg|thumb|right|A rear view of the Elgato Thunderbolt dock showing the available ports]] Elgato introduced a [[Thunderbolt (interface)|Thunderbolt]] [[docking station]] in June 2014. A computer is plugged into the dock using a Thunderbolt port in order to gain access to the dock's three USB ports, audio jacks, HDMI and ethernet. It is typically used to plug a Macbook into an office setting (printer, monitor, keyboard) or to provide additional ports not available in the Macbook Air.<ref name="cnettt">{{cite news|title=Add a slew of ports to your MacBook with the Elgato Thunderbolt Dock|date=April 4, 2014|url=http://www.cnet.com/products/elgato-thunderbolt-dock/|publisher=CNET|accessdate=August 14, 2014}}</ref><ref name="registertwodlh">{{cite news|title=Plugging the gaps in today's Macs: Elgato Thunderbolt Dock|first=Bob|last=Dormon|date=June 3, 2014|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2014/06/03/review_elgato_thunderbolt_dock/|accessdate=August 14, 2014|newspaper=The Register}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato Thunderbolt Dock review: This sleek station will supercharge your laptop-powered workspace|publisher=TheNextWeb|url=https://thenextweb.com/gadgets/2014/04/14/elgato-thunderbolt-dock-review/|accessdate=August 14, 2014|first=Nick|last=Summers|date=April 14, 2014}}</ref> A review in ''The Register'' said it was compact and useful, but Windows users should consider a USB 3.0 dock.<ref name="registertwodlh"/> ''The Register'' and CNET disagreed on whether it was competitively priced.<ref name="cnettt"/><ref name="registertwodlh"/> Reviews in TechRadar and Macworld gave it 4 out of 5 stars.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.macworld.co.uk/review/mac-accessories/elgato-thunderbolt-dock-review-3532358/|publisher=MacWorld|title=Elgato Thunderbolt Dock review|first=Andrew|last=Harrison |date=July 23, 2014|accessdate=August 14, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato Thunderbolt Dock review:Connect several devices to your computer by plugging in a single cable|first=Alan|last=Stonebridge|date=May 1, 2014|url=http://www.techradar.com/reviews/pc-mac/peripherals/input-devices/general-input-devices/elgato-thunderbolt-dock-1246495/review}}</ref>
===Thunderbolt SSD=== [[File:Thunderbolt Drive+ sideview 01.jpg|thumb|left|The Elgato Thunderbolt Drive+]] Elgato introduced two firewire external hard drives in September 2012 called Thunderbolt Drive.<ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato's Thunderbolt SSD brings no noise, brings the pain(less) operation|first=Daniel|last=Cooper|url=https://www.engadget.com/2012/01/09/elgato-thunderbolt-ssd/|publisher=Engadget|accessdate=August 14, 2014}}</ref> Benchmark tests by MacWorld and Tom's Hardware said that the hard drive was slower than other products they tested, despite being connected through a faster Thunderbolt port, rather than Firewire.<ref>{{cite news|title=Nine External Thunderbolt Storage Devices, Rounded Up|first=Andrew|last=Ku|date=July 15, 2012|publisher=Tom's Hardware|url=http://www.tomshardware.com/reviews/my-book-thunderbolt-duo-pegasus-r4-2big,3222-2.html|accessdate=August 14, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato's bus-powered Thunderbolt SSD|first=Kean|last=Bartleman|publisher=Macworld|date=May 2, 2012|url=http://www.macworld.com/article/1166646/elgatos_bus_powered_thunderbolt_ssd.html|accessdate=August 14, 2014}}</ref> The following year, in 2013, Elgato replaced them with similar drives identified as "Thunderbolt Drive +", which added USB 3.0 support and was claimed to be faster than the previous iteration.<ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato Thunderbolt Drive+ SSD earns its 'plus' tag through USB 3.0 and brisk speeds|first=Jon|last=Fingas|url=https://www.engadget.com/2013/11/08/elgato-thunderbolt-drive-plus/|date=November 8, 2013|accessdate=August 14, 2014|publisher=Engadget}}</ref> A CNET review of a Thunderbolt Drive+ drive gave it a 4.5 out of 5 star rating. It said the drive was "blazing fast" and "the most portable drive to date" but was also expensive.<ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato Thunderbolt Drive+ review: Blazing fast portable drive|date=February 14, 2014|url=http://www.cnet.com/products/elgato-thunderbolt-drive-plus-256gb/|publisher=CNET|accessdate=August 14, 2014 }}</ref> An article in ''The Register'' explained that the original drives introduced in 2012 didn't perform well in benchmark tests, but the newer "plus" version had impressive speed results during testing.<ref>{{cite news|title=Vulture wraps claws around Elgato Thunderbolt Drive+ portable SSD|date=March 6, 2014|first=Bob|last=Dormon|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2014/03/06/elgato_thunderbolt_plus_portable_ssd_drive/|accessdate=August 14, 2014|newspaper=The Register}}</ref>
==Gaming== Game Capture HD, which connects to gaming consoles to record gameplay, was introduced in 2012. It was created in response to gamers that were hacking EyeTV products for gameplay recording.<ref>{{cite news|title=What is ... Elgato's Game Capture HD|first=Adam |last=Turner|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=July 16, 2012}}</ref> The device connects between a gaming console and the TV and is powered by a USB connection. It captures video as the console sends it to the television, compresses and stores it.<ref name="gizmodo">{{cite news|title=Elgato Game Capture HD 60: Australian Review|date=October 29, 2014|first=Campbell|last=Simpson|publisher=Gizmodo Australia|url=http://www.gizmodo.com.au/2014/10/elgato-game-capture-hd-60-australian-review/|accessdate=October 30, 2014}}</ref> A review in iPhone Life gave it 4 out of 5 stars and noted that it could also be used to record iPad games with the right setup.<ref>{{cite news|title=Record iPad Video with Elgato Game Capture HD|first=Mike|last=Riley|date=July 15, 2013|url=http://www.iphonelife.com/blog/177/elgato-game-capture-hd-review|newspaper=iphone life magazine|accessdate=September 2, 2014}}</ref>
In October 2014 Elgato released a new version called HD 60. It recorded in 60 frames per second and 1080p high definition video (compared to the previous Game Capture HD's 1080p30 or 720p60), whereas typical low-end video game recording devices capture in 720p and 30 frames per second. ''The Telegraph'' gave it four out of five stars.<ref>{{cite news|title=Elgato Game Capture HD 60 review|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/video-games/video-game-reviews/11158250/Elgato-Game-Capture-HD-60-review.html|accessdate=October 30, 2014|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=October 17, 2014|first=Tom|last=Hoggins}}</ref> A review in Gizmodo said that it captured extremely high-quality footage, but it may be higher-end than needed for many gamers that would be satisfied with the recording features built into the console.<ref name="gizmodo"/>
In June 2018, [[Corsair Components]] acquired Elgato Gaming.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.engadget.com/2018/06/27/corsair-acquires-elgato-gaming/|title=Corsair buys Elgato's gaming business to get into livestreaming|work=Engadget|access-date=2018-06-27|language=en-US}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [https://www.elgato.com Official website]
{{Home theater PC (application software)}}
[[Category:Digital video recorders]] [[Category:Technology companies established in 1992]] [[Category:Television technology]] [[Category:Television time shifting technology]]

Enkū was born in [[Mino Province]], present-day Gifu Prefecture, in 1632 and died in Seki in 1695.{{cite web |url=http://www.city.seki.gifu.jp/kankou/seki/enku.html |script-title=ja:円空館 |trans-title=Enku Museum |language=Japanese |publisher=[[Seki, Gifu|Seki City]] |accessdate=8 March 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.axscom.co.jp/portfolio/museum/02513/index.php |script-title=ja:関市円空館 |trans-title=Enku Museum, Seki |language=Japanese |publisher=[[AXS Satow]] |accessdate=8 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140108141343/http://www.axscom.co.jp/portfolio/museum/02513/index.php |archivedate=8 January 2014 |df= }} ==See also== {{Commons category|Enku Museum}} * [[Japanese sculpture]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{ja icon}} [http://www.city.seki.gifu.jp/kankou/seki/enku.html Homepage] {{DEFAULTSORT:Enku Museum}} [[Category:Seki, Gifu]] [[Category:Museums in Gifu Prefecture]] [[Category:Museums of Japanese art]] [[Category:Art museums and galleries in Japan]] [[Category:Japanese sculpture]] [[Category:Biographical museums in Japan]] {{Japan-museum-stub}}
